When I first read the article,it all seemed totally justified to me. I thought that these words since coming from such a big guy must all be gems and indeed most of them are,they could actually help a graduate enter the professional world smoothly. But when i read the comments below(all of them), I quite agreed with these people too,the people who have worked in the industry on the other side. Some of the points raised by the author are acceptable while on some points, he seems to be biased. The newcomers are not as much efficient but they are not paid as much either. Also the firm doesn't do them a favor,it is finally going to receive their services. The company does spend time and money on the newcomers but in a lot of cases, the employees are also hooked by bonds,so finally the firm manages to get back what it invested over the period.
The Hierarchy is something that is seldom challenged and could not be until the environment is conducive to question asking and innovations.If in a firm, a particular work is done in a certain way and something that an individual suggests requires some "inconvenient change", then I think the author will agree it is most likely that the former will win. Then the enthusiasm to ask questions and provide suggestions is bound to die out.
Having said that, I would not let the good slip out for the perfect. Some of the points in this letter are actually worth some thought and could prove fruitful for a lot of fellows out there.

Why are we coddling equity firms? Cory Booker, nauseated by the criticisms of equity capital, should remember its most egregious example and be nauseated by the 3 centuries equity firms trafficked human beings. Laurens & Austin and 100s of equity firms created a fiscal and legal infrastructure for the then world's largest profit center in London, Newport, Charleston and places on both sides of the Atlantic. Slavery was risky. Disease wiped out the investment; abolitionists opposed it. But the profits reaped made the capital risks and human costs seem miniscule.

When slavery ended, did equity capital reform? Trace its history carefully and you arrive at Mitt Romney—and Cory Booker, Harold Ford and Steve Rattner, who praise its benefits without reference to its morality or history, seeing only efficient good and business growth in seeing the world as a balance sheet.

It's not always about Republican or Democratic, but who is moral, true to the deepest human principles not attached to profits or partisanship. The gilded poison fruits of its investments, its historic, global role celebrates a special breed of robber barons who strip human dignity for the balance sheet. Barack is right to call attention to the difference. And when a prominent politician feels nausea for the criticism of equity capital but not a moment's discomfort over its balance sheet approach and the human carnage that marks its history, who thinks equity capital has charged?

3. Indians are dramatic whiners. Lamenting, whining and grumbling are the main national sports, more popular than Cricket or Hockey. The author is also a team-member.

4. Indian companies are masters at playing labor arbitrage but do ZERO innovation. How many Apples, Googles and Microsofts have we produced? All we have are a bunch of Infosyses & Wipros - that have contributed very little to the science of software, computing or management.

Still, I believe that one or two(or twenty) public hangings on the steps of the New York Stock Exchange would go a long way toward solving more than a few of them.

Richard: I agree with some of your comments, but see the larger picture a little differently.

Under present circumstances, it's easy to "hate" Wall Street's depradations (and its manipulators); however, like a cat eating a bird, these Masters of the Universe are "doing what comes natural." B schools do teach them what you say, as do their business peers. They can grasp huge windfalls relatively easily (given their positions) via use of complex financial instruments, and the massive profits they can make currently create their own protected "bubble" of privilege.

Fundamentally, however, the very raison d'etre of a corporation - now and in decades past - is to make profits. Employees are expendable. Socio-economic issues are irrelevant. Long-term strategies? Hell, no: it's "what can you do for me this quarter?"

Corporations are not people, and they are not immoral. They are amoral. They WILL do what is in their best interests. And, given current compensation systems, their best interests are SHORT TERM ones. This creates the impetus for enormous greed and "anti-social" behavior, and the downsides (of risk, waste, or pollution) will mostly be off-loaded to the public.

The ONLY cure for this (and it is a partial one, at best) is careful, strict, continuous, and effective regulation.

Yes, the childishness and desperate need for deference of the masters of the universe are irksome; but they really don't change realities on the ground.

We still have a work force that is inadequately prepared to perform the jobs Bill Gates and others have open and can't fill -- and will need to ship elsewhere if they want the work to get done; and we still have legions of corporatists outside Wall Street that see nothing wrong in offshoring our middle class jobs, that our people ARE competent to perform, basically because their B-school professors taught them that there is no higher priority than dramatically cutting costs and increasing profits this quarter; and we still have governments at all levels that, if they had their druthers, would push their collective percentage of GDP above Greece's or Italy's, while still actually producing next to nothing; and we have an electorate a significant part of which (though apparently a dwindling percentage) believes that eating off the plates of others is acceptable behavior, as are the debt and deficits such behavior produces. We have a lot of intractable problems that have little or nothing to do Lloyd Blankfein and Jamie Dimon.

I have little love for these privileged, insulated reptiles. But hating them exclusively (yes, hating is the proper word, as a lot of these yahoos are evil) is a distraction from the entirety of ills that beset us.

Despite their fundamental greasiness, they're not even a large part of our problems.

In what's going to be a bare-knuckled Presidential election with huge potential for spill-over into House and Senate races and thus impact on our standard of living, Booker’s comments showed more of a wistful rather than realistic understanding of what this election is about.

Yes, Booker later said he believed Obama's attacks on Romney's record at Bain were legitimate. That’s certainly not what the Romney campaign will remind voters was said.

Booker needs to keep in mind that one of the ways private equity, (which Booker seems to hold above criticism), accumulates vast wealth has been by gutting company pension funds, often through planned bankruptcy for that purpose, and then dumping the pensioners onto the Federal government at a much reduced benefit - a benefit which workers often paid for with deductions from their wages. .

It’s obvious from looking at the Ryan economic policy model (wishful thinking) and the evisceration of American middle class income and jobs that generate middle class income, that the Republican concept of economics for the 99% is Hobbes’ short and brutal existence in the state of nature, as Hobbes’ himself succinctly explained it.

This election is going to be about who has a record, not just promises, working to restore the vitality of our nation’s middle class. If Booker finds pointing out the damage done by Bain Capital nauseating, he’s missed the issue. No doubt Romney and the Wall Streeters hope all voters will miss that issue.

I moved to Canada 10 years ago. I was a recent law graduate and I upgraded my education at a law school in Canada instead of writing exams by myself. That taught me a lot!
1. I agree the onus is on the candidate to learn and improve their English language skills. But 'hard to understand' implies that the author has no idea of what happens when learn English in a non-white country. I went to an English medium school in India and, like most of the middle class, studied in English throughout. We used some words/sentences at home but preferred (and still prefer) to speak in Hindi. When I first started school in Canada, it was strange to go on and on in English the whole time. Not (too) hard but strange. But it gets better with time and practice. As for writing, we use a long winded floral style in India. It is a cultural thing, left over from the British Raj.
2. and 3. The author has clearly never worked in India. They beat that out of you! Deference to elders and authority is so deeply ingrained that you- KPMG - should take the lead in explaining to your Indian graduates that nobody will take offense at new ideas, questions and out-of-box thinking. I did not know I could go speak to a Professor after class. It is also considered morally corrupt to beat your own drum in Indian and Chinese cultures. I have had to learn this the hard way. And I still find hard to do it.
4. and 5. are applicable to all industries but young graduates are also a little lost. Give it time.

This story is just another example of a frivolous and ultimately pointless patent lawsuit.  The patent system was founded with the intent of helping inventors protect their ideas, which would have the effect of encouraging inventing.  It worked for hundreds of years as countless inventions we know consider vital to our daily lives were invented by Americans, but that time is coming to an end.  With the explosion of the tech industry our patent system is being exposed as an outdated and broken system.  Companies now have to spend hundreds of millions  of dollars buying patents, such as Microsoft's purchase of patents from AOL a portion of which Microsoft then sold to Facebook for 550 million dollars, but don't purchase those patents with the intent on creating a new product.  Companies are so afraid of being caught in a patent lawsuit they purchase patents with the sole purpose of protecting themselves from a patent lawsuit.  Caught in the middle of this massive waste of money and time are the inventors supposedly protected by the patent system.  The patent system has shown itself to be too outdated to protect an inventor in the technological age.  The patent system was never written with technology in mind, and it's time the patent system be changed in order to actually protect and encourage invention in the technological age.

Richard Luettgen:

I don't want to debate the critical merits of the word "Balderdash", It is the kind of word that gets flung when both, the posture and the postulation, are inherently defensive (Baloney, Bull-Puckey complete this trio.) . I'll just set about unpacking the biases in your post:

"but to suggest that the industries they work in are not at the center of government's ability to provide critical services in these cities is just the sort of collectivist excess "

And how naive to think that these industries would be providing these "critical services" if they were not actually benefiting them, too? Altruism? A small collective whose excess should never be questioned or regulated.

" I'm a consultant who provides no services to it, and depend on them to the same extent anybody else does."

Have you considered this: that Obama would like to keep
Wall Street guessing; and so Obama is playing a politcal parlance and a bit of deference ; one of a very "delicate balance".

The President is taking it very easy on Wall St. and needs to make clear what tough is. He should be thundering like Teddy Roosevelt about how we got into this mess and what it will take to turn around 30 years of conservative nonsense.

Break up the big banks. Bring back Glass Steagall. Shut the revolving door between Wall St. and its regulators. Have investors or taxpayers pay for credit ratings, not issuers. Insist on a real (10-20%) down payment, as Warren Buffett suggested. Write down the mortgages of underwater homeowners, to get the debt to income ratio down from 115% to 80% where it was in 1990.

Then tackle the pink elephant with bat wings, a birthday hat and a trumpet in the room: The $650 billion goods trade deficit, say half to two-thirds of our employment problem. Which part of taxing corporations for the wage differential or outright banning off-shoring doesn't he understand (when these firms do so with the intent of providing the goods or services to U.S. customers).

Globalization is not working for us...so do something about it!

Paul Krugman gets it. When will the Democrats and the President start to wake up? Who's got their tongue and if so, why not get a Constitutional Amendment out there to take the money out of politics, via term limits and campaign contribution limits?

The fact that we, as a country, have the good fortune to quibble about tax cuts and carried interest and other such nonsense is a sure sign that this country has had it too good, for too long.  It's a shame that we are too ignorant of history to understand the real sacrifices that past generations have made to ensure that we could enjoy our lives without thinking about threats greater than a tax increase.  Considering all that is wrong in our world today, it is disappointing that many of us are only concerned with whether we pay 35% in taxes, or 38%.  Past generations would be quite disappointed at our obsession over such triviality. Future generations will be disappointed, too.
